von Willebrand disease type 2A and TTP are opposites!  

vWD 2A =
⬇️VWF large multimer (cut up too much by
ADAMTS13)
⬇️binding to platelets =⬆️ bleeding

TTP = Autoantibody to ADAMTS13 (or in congenital not made)
⬆️VWF large multimers (not cut up)
⬆️ platelet binding = thrombosis https://t.co/rmri3tU6lI

B cells in allograft produce allo Abs against residual recipient RBCs  
DAT+ hemolytic anemia 
Brisk hemolysis days +5-15 after transplant

We have many debates on CAR versus bispecifics.

But for those who desperately imminently need therapy now for progressions- bispecifics beat CAR out of the park, IMO.

Everyday in my clinic there is selection bias in favor of ⬆️ PFS for CAR-T.

Aggressive disease, rapidly rising light chains: Give bispecifics 

Indolent progressions, planning for next tx in advance: Think CAR.

Cilta-cel real world PFS will be stellar for this reason, IMO

So to summarize:

1) In the real-world, teclistamab has comparable response rates.
2) The duration of follow-up is far too short to make more meaningful conclusions regarding efficacy
3) There is a selection bias as pts with really advanced/aggressive disease get bispecs.

END.

Until I have stronger data to suggest otherwise, I would view teclistamab and elranatamab like Coke and Pepsi.

Just like daratumumab and isatuximab. 

Much to learn regarding sequencing of BCMA therapies- I hope for more prospective data in this space.

That doesnt mean bispecifics are worse than CAR-T.

They just are more accessible to patients in need.

And they are often used in desparate situations- as the above table shows.

Would we expect similar results with elranatamab?

I suspect that real-world performance of teclistamab will actually be poorer than the trial. And that is because of patient selection.

Whereas real-world performance of cilta-cel may also be stellar. Again due to patient selection.

Such a short duration of follow-up will lead to an inaccurate PFS estimate.

With further follow-up, the PFS may be longer, or shorter than this estimate. It is hard to conclude much regarding PFS or durability of response with all these datasets currently.

Summarized in table.

Key lessons:

⭐️Patients with advanced disease get teclistamab (more than 40% with extramedullary disease, 30-50% already received prior BCMA therapy)
⭐️The duration of follow-up in all these studies is far too short (1-3 months!)
⭐️Response rates similar https://t.co/3fdEHKAW3J

We have 4 datasets with n>50 using teclistamab

1)@ShoMidha Dana Farber experience presented at #IMS23
2) International Myeloma Foundation immunotherapy subgroup experience presented at #IMS23
3) @MeeraMohanMD multi-center at #ASH23 
4) @DimaDanai multi-center at #ASH23

Lets first prime ourselves by recapping teclistamab trial data, published here:

https://t.co/naBoZ4cv3u

N=165,
Overall response rate=63%
Median duration of response=18 months
PFS= 11.3 months
Median prior lines=5
77.6% triple refractory.

Prior BCMA exposure not allowed. https://t.co/iSPsIGBmTm

In my clinical practice, patients with advanced/refractory MM with aggressive disease get bispecifics, whereas those with more indolent/slow relapses get cilta-cel.

What this will lead to is a selection bias- with poor efficacy of bispecifics in real life compared to CAR-T

Bispecifics in the real-world: What do we know so far, and what lessons can we learn?
